title: Relationships Between Selected Black-throated Blue Warbler Characteristics and Mass
description: In this analysis, I investigated the relationships between various characteristics of black-throated blue warblers and their mass using multiple linear regression. The analysis began with exploratory visualizations, including scatterplots and beeswarm plots, to identify potential linear relationships and outliers. Then, I performed multiple linear regression to quantitatively describe the relationships between mass and other recorded features such as wing length, sex, bill dimensions, and tarsus length. Model selection was based on diagnostic plots, Adjusted R-squared, and AIC scores to ensure the best balance between model fit and complexity.
contents:
Summary
In this report, I explore the relationships between selected
black-throated blue warbler characteristics and mass. First, I visually
explore the data. Then, I use multiple linear regression to describe the
relationship.



1. Exploratory Visualization
Exploratory scatterplots exploring linear relationship (also
useful for identifying notable outliers and having some initial thoughts
about homoscedasticity)
Beeswarm plot for visualizing the relationship between bird mass
and elevation of the sample plot (low, mid, or high)



2. Multiple linear regression
Exploring
relationships between bird mass (dependent variable) and other recorded
features (explanatory variables)



Comparing the different
models:
Observation of how the coefficients change in the different
models as predictor variables change
Assessment of model fit (Adjusted R-squared)
Diagnostic plots for exploring model assumptions
(homoscedasticity and distribution of residuals and Cook’s
distance)
Comparison of the quality (balance: model fit / complexity) of
the different models (AIC)
Selected model outcomes






Dependent variable:








mass




wing_r


0.071***



(0.015)






sexM


-1.038***



(0.068)






bill_depth


0.112




(0.148)






bill_culmen


0.138***



(0.047)






tarsus1


0.061*



(0.034)






Constant


3.384***



(1.173)








Observations


667


R2

0.331


Adjusted R2

0.325


Residual Std. Error


0.588 (df = 661)


F Statistic


65.262*** (df = 5; 661)




Note:


p<0.1; p<0.05;
p<0.01


Justification of the model
selection
Diagnostic plots for exploring model assumptions reveal normally
distributed and homoscedastic residuals for all models. In the evaluated
models, Adjusted R-squared (a measure of how much the variance in the
dependent variable is explained by the explanatory variables in the
model) increases with the addition of more predictor variables. AIC
shows comparative scores reflecting the balance between the predictive
capabilities of the model (model fit) and the increase in complexity due
to the addition of variables. When comparing the initial models, the
model with the highest number of variables (lm5) showed the best balance
in model fit/complexity (i.e., the benefits in model fit of adding the
additional variables outweigh the increased complexity). However, as the
addition of the age_banded variable determined an increase in the AIC, I
decided to try a new model (lm6) by removing this variable from the lm5
model. Showing a better balance between model fit and complexity (lower
AIC), lm6 was the selected model.
Interpretation of lm6
coefficients
Wing length coefficient (wing_r 0.071): on average, a 1 mm
increase in wing length is associated with a 0.071 g increase in bird
mass.
Sex coefficient (sexM -1.038): on average, if everything else is
fixed, we expect males to have a 1.038 g less mass than females
(reference level).
Bill cross-section depth coefficient (bill_depth 0.112): on
average, a 1 mm increase in bill cross-section depth is associated with
a 0.112 g increase in bird mass.
Bill culmen length coefficient (bill_culmen 0.138): on average, a
1 mm increase in bill culmen length is associated with a 0.138 g
increase in bird mass.
Tarsus length coefficient (tarsus1 0.061): on average, a 1 mm
increase in tarsus length is associated with a 0.061 g increase in bird
mass.
Citation
Rodenhouse, N., R. Holmes, S. Sillett, and M. Webster. 2019.
Black-throated Blue Warbler capture histories, Hubbard Brook
Experimental Forest, 1986 - 2010 ver 4. Environmental Data Initiative.
https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/ea985022acfdb76cd7beeaf8da6c39b1

title: Exploration of Data for Marine Turtles of Species Green and Loggerhead Captured in Shark Bay, Australia
description: In this analysis, I explored the relationship between carapace length and width in green and loggerhead turtles through data visualization and linear regression, which quantitatively described this relationship. A strong positive correlation was found, with 93% of the variance in carapace width being explained by length. Additionally, I compared the carapace lengths between green and loggerhead turtles using a two-sample t-test, which showed no significant difference in mean lengths between the species. Finally, I assessed the association between species and the occurrence of burrowing barnacles using a chi-square test, revealing a significant association between the two variables.
contents:
Summary
In this report, I explore the relationship between sea turtle
carapace length and width by visualizing the data and performing linear
regression to quantitative describe this relationship. Then, I
statistically compare the carapace lengths between green and loggerhead
turtles. For this comparison I perform a two-sample t-tests
(significance level (\(\alpha\)) of
0.05). Lastly, I explore the association between species (green and
loggerhead) and the occurrence of burrowing barnacles through a
chi-square test.



1.
Relationship between sea turtle carapace length and width
Exploratory visualization



Linear
regression: quantitative description of the relationship between sea
turtle carapace length and width


Call:
lm(formula = width ~ length, data = sea_turtles)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-16.4171  -2.1140  -0.0254   2.2046   9.9637 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)  5.95970    1.29609   4.598 6.46e-06 ***
length       0.86214    0.01396  61.775  < 2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 3.396 on 280 degrees of freedom
  (1 observation deleted due to missingness)
Multiple R-squared:  0.9316,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.9314 
F-statistic:  3816 on 1 and 280 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


There is a linear relationship between sea turtles’ carapace length
(cm) and width (cm). Linear model summary: \(\beta\)1 = 0.86 cm
cm-1, p < 0.001, R2 = 0.93, Pearson’s
r = 0.97).
This summary shows that, on average, we expect carapace width to
increase by 0.86 centimeter for each one centimeter increase in length.
At the same time, the R2 shows that 93.16% of the variance in
carapace width is predictable from the length. Carapace length and width
are strongly, and significantly, positively correlated (Pearson’s
r = 0.97, p < 0.001). Diagnostic plots (not included) show
normally distributed and homoscedastic residuals.
2.
Comparison of carapace lengths between green and loggerhead turtles
Exploratory
visualization of distribution



Bell-shaped histogram reflecting a normal distribution (slightly
positive skew for both green and loggerhead turtles). This normal
distribution is also shown by the quantile-quantile plot with a nearly
linear relationship.
Test
selection: statistically compare carapace lengths for green and
loggerhead turtles
For comparing the carapace lengths for green and loggerhead turtles I
will perform a 2-sample t-test. With this test we can compare the means
of the two groups and know the probability of having obtained sample
means at least this different if they were drawn from populations with
the same mean (p-value). The selection of this test is based on the fact
that thanks to the histograms and quantile-quantile plots we can see
that we satisfy the assumptions about distribution, where carapace
lengths for green and loggerhead turtles follow a relatively normal
distribution (bell-shaped histogram and quantile-quantile plot with an
almost linear relationship). In case of not satisfying this assumption,
we could use a rank-based alternative (Mann-Whitney U test).
2-Sample T-Test



On average, carapace length of green turtles is slightly greater than
that of loggerhead turtles (92.64 \(\pm\) 15.78 and 89.91 \(\pm\) 11.44 cm, respectively; mean \(\pm\) 1 standard deviation). The absolute
difference in means is 2.73cm (a 2.98% difference). The effect size is
negligible (Cohen’s d = 0.19) and the difference in means
(significance level (\(\alpha\)) of
0.05) is not significant (Welch two-sample t-test: t(244.17) = 1.65, p =
9.98e-02).
3.
Comparison of the the occurrence of burrowing barnacles on green versus
loggerhead turtles.
Contingency
table containing the counts and proportions of each species with and
without burrowing barnacles observed
Table 1. Counts and proportions of green and
loggerhead turtles with (Yes) and without (No) burrowing barnacles.
Data: Heithaus & Thomson (2019).


Species


No


Yes


green


87% (164)


13% (24)


loggerhead


69% (66)


31% (29)


Chi-square
test for assessing associationn between species (green and loggerhead)
and the occurrence of burrowing barnacles



For green turtles, burrowing barnacles were present in 24 individuals
and absent in 164. For loggerhead turtles, the presence/absence of
burrowing barnacles was 29 and 66 respectively. There is a significant
association between species (green or loggerhead) and presence/absence
of burrowing barnacles. In other words, species and occurrence of
burrowing barnacles are non-independent (\(\chi\)2(1) = 11.94, p =
5.5e-04).
Citation
Heithaus, M. and J. Thomson. 2019. Marine turtles captured during
haphazard at-sea surveys in Shark Bay, Australia from February 2008 to
December 2013 ver 4. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/7696e20214fbf84f25d664ff7dc8050c

title: Trends in Steller Sea Lion Pup Populations for Five Alaskan Rookeries
description: In this analysis, I explored trends in Steller sea lion pup populations across five Alaskan rookeries (Sugarloaf, Marmot, Forrester Complex, Chowiet, and Hazy). The analysis involved data wrangling to calculate the mean pup counts by site and year, followed by data visualization to examine the population trends over time. The visual exploration revealed a decline in pup populations at Sugarloaf, Marmot, and Chowiet since 1980, while Hazy showed an increase. The Forrester Complex also showed an overall increase, but a notable drop in 2002 requires further investigation.
contents:
Summary
In this report I explore the trends in Steller sea lion pup
populations for five Alaskan rookeries (Sugarloaf, Marmot, Forrester
Complex, Chowiet, and Hazy). First, I wrangle the data to get the mean
value of pup counts by site and year. Second, I visually explore the
trends for each site.



Data wrangling:
Find the mean value of pup counts by site and year
Only keep observations from sites Sugarloaf, Marmot, Forrester
Complex, Chowiet, and Hazy
Only columns containing the site name, year, and pup
count
Rename pup counts as steller_pups






Data Visualization



Figure 1. Steller sea lion pup populations per year
for five Alaskan rookeries (Sugarloaf, Marmot, Forrester Complex,
Chowiet, and Hazy). Blue points indicate recorded counts of Steller sea
lion pups. In the case that several counts were recorded for the same
year, the plotted value represents the mean of those recorded counts.
Data: Fritz et al. (2015).
Trends
in Steller sea lion pup populations for the five Alaskan rookeries
Charts show a decline in Steller sea lion pup populations from 1980
onwards for the sites Sugarloaf, Marmot, and Chowiet. In contrast, Hazy
records an increase in pups population. Forrester Complex shows an
increase in pup counts since 1980, however, a 2002 record of 0 pups is
confusing. More analysis is required to explain this sudden drop in
population.
Citation
Fritz, Lowell; Sweeney, Kathryn; Lynn, Morgan; Gelatt, Thomas;
Gilpatrick, James; Towell, Rodney (2015). Counts of Alaska Steller sea
lion pups conducted on rookeries in Alaska from 1961-06-22 to 2015-07-18
(NCEI Accession 0128189). NOAA National Centers for Environmental
Information. Dataset. https://doi.org/10.7289/v5862ddr.

title: Comparison of Total Length for Female Lizards of Species CNTE and CNUN
description: In this analysis, I compared the total length of female lizards from two species: CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus, the Colorado Checkered lizard) and CNUN (Cnemidophorus uniparens, the Desert Grassland lizard). Using data collected from the Jornada Basin LTER between 1989 and 2006, I employed a two-sample t-test to assess the significance of the difference in total length between the two species, and quantified the effect size using Cohen’s d. The analysis revealed that CNTE females are significantly longer on average than CNUN females, with a large effect size.
contents:
Introduction
This report provides a comparison of the total length for female
lizards of the species CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus, the Colorado
Checkered lizard) and CNUN (Cnemidophorus uniparens, the Desert
Grassland lizard). Data was colected at Jornada Basin Long Term
Ecological Research (LTER) from 1989 to 2006 using pitfall traps that
were checked once a week at the minimum (Lightfoot, 2017). Following
exploratory data visualization, total length of female lizards from the
species CNTE and CNUN were compared by a two-sample t-tests
(significance level (\(\alpha\)) of
0.05) and differences were described by Cohen’s d effect size.
All analyses are in R version 4.0.2 using RStudio version 1.3.1056.






Figure 1. Total lengths (mm) of female lizards of
the species CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus, the Colorado Checkered
lizard) and CNUN (Cnemidophorus uniparens, the Desert Grassland lizard).
Orange (CNTE, Cnemidophorus tessalatus) and teal (CNUN, Cnemidophorus
uniparens) points indicate individual observations for total length
(millimeters) of female lizards. Box endpoints indicate the
25th and 75th percentile values. The black line
and black point within the box indicate the total length median and mean
value respectively. Data: Lightfoot (2017).
Table 2. Descriptive statistics (mean, standard
deviation, and sample size) for total length (mm) of female lizards from
the species CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus) and CNUN (Cnemidophorus
uniparens). Data: Lightfoot (2017).


Species


Mean total lenght (mm)


Standard deviation (mm)


Sample Size


CNTE


244.9


47.3


28


CNUN


147.6


34.6


40


Distributions of total length (plots not included) for female lizards
of the species CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus) and CNUN (Cnemidophorus
uniparens) were relatively normal and symmetric (bell-shaped histogram
and quantile-quantile plot with an almost linear relationship).



On average, the total length of CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus)
females is greater than that of CNUN (Cnemidophorus uniparens) females
(244.89 \(\pm\) 47.32 and 147.6 \(\pm\) 34.55 mm, respectively; mean \(\pm\) 1 standard deviation). The absolute
difference in means is 97.29 mm (a 49.58% difference). The effect size
is large (Cohen’s d = 2.42) and the difference in means is
significant (Welch two-sample t-test: t(46.43) = 9.28, p =
3.75e-12).
Summary
Exploratory data analysis reveals that, on average, the total length
of female lizards of CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus) is greater than
that of CNUN (Cnemidophorus uniparens). This difference in total length
is significant, and the effect size is large.
Citations
Lightfoot, D. 2017. Lizard pitfall trap data (LTER-II, LTER-III) ver
36. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/ff37b4cace16a9943575f3fd7067064e

title: Association Between Respondents’ Political Affiliation and Environmentalist Self-identification
description: In this analysis, I explored the association between respondents' political affiliation (Conservative or Liberal) and their self-identification as environmentalists using a chi-squared test. The analysis, based on survey data from 1,331 U.S. respondents collected in August 2017, aimed to determine whether there is a significant relationship between political affiliation and environmentalist self-identification. The chi-squared test revealed a significant association, indicating that these two variables are not independent.
contents:
Introduction
This report provides an exploratory analysis of the association
between respondents’ political affiliation (Conservative or Liberal) and
environmentalist self-identification (perception of respondents
regarding whether they consider themselves environmentalists). Data was
collected in August 2017 from an online panel of 1,331 anonymous,
nationwide U.S respondents (Andrews Forest LTER Site and C. Batavia.
2019). The association between respondents’ political affiliation and
environmentalist self-identification was explored by a chi-squared test
(significance level (\(\alpha\)) of
0.05). All analyses are in R version 4.0.2 using RStudio version
1.3.1056.






Table 1. Counts and proportions of Conservative or
Liberal survey respondents who responded “Yes”, “No” and “Unsure” to the
statement “I consider myself an environmentalist.” Data: Andrews Forest
LTER Site and C. Batavia (2019).




Yes


No


Unsure


Conservative


34% (213)


50% (318)


16% (102)


Liberal


54% (281)


24% (128)


22% (114)





There is a significant association between respondents’ political
affiliation (Conservative or Liberal) and environmentalist
self-identification (perception of respondents regarding whether they
consider themselves environmentalists). In other words, political
affiliation and environmentalist self-identification are non-independent
(\(\chi\)2(2) = 81.24,
p <2e-16).
Summary
Survey data exploration reveals that there is a significant
association (i.e. non-independence) between respondents’ political
affiliation and environmentalist self-identification.
Citations
Andrews Forest LTER Site and C. Batavia. 2019. Influences on
charitable giving for conservation: Online survey data of 1,331
respondents across the US, August 2017 ver 3. Environmental Data
Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/926e6270e324a1322a900da14d38b96c

title: Exploratory Analysis of Juvenile Snowshoe Hares in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest
description: In this analysis, I explored the data from a capture-recapture study of juvenile snowshoe hares (Lepus americanus) conducted in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest between 1999 and 2012. The study aimed to investigate trends in hare population over time, compare the weights of male and female juveniles using two-sample t-tests and Cohen’s d for effect size, and examine the relationship between their weight and hind foot length through simple linear regression analysis.
contents:
1. Introduction
This report provides an exploratory analysis of juvenile snowshoe
hare (Lepus americanus) surveyed in a capture-recapture study conducted
in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest from 1999 to 2012 (Kielland et
al. 2017). Specifically, this report presents: an exploration of the
total number of juvenile snowshoe hares sampled by year in the Bonanza
Creek Experimental Forest (1999-2012); a comparison of weights for
juvenile male and female snowshoe hares; finally, an analysis of the
relationship between juvenile weight and hind foot length.
2. Data and analyses
Snowshoe hare data was collected and made available by Dr. Knut
Kielland and colleges at the Bonanza Creek Long Term Ecological Research
Station in Alaska. The data contains 3197 observations from
capture-recapture studies of snowshoe hares, conducted from 1999 to
2012. Following exploratory data visualization, juvenile male and female
snowshoe hares weights were compared by a two-sample t-tests
(significance level (\(\alpha\)) of
0.05) and differences between groups were described by Cohen’s
d effect size. Finally, the relationship between juvenile
snowshoe hare weight and hind foot length was explored by simple linear
regression. All analyses are in R version 4.0.2 using RStudio version
1.3.1056.
3. Exploratory findings
A. Annual juvenile
snowshoe hare trap counts



Figure 1. Total number of juvenile snowshoe hare
(observed via trap capture) by year.
Table 1. Descriptive statistics (mean, median, minimum
and maximum counts) for annual counts of juvenile snowshoe hare
trappings. Data: Kielland et al. (2017).


Annual Mean


Annual Median


Maximum Count


Minimum Count


31.5


18.5


126


2





Juvenile snowshoe hare (observed via trap capture) were counted by
year. The minimum and maximum counts of juvenile hare trappings were 2
and 126 respectively. The mean annual number of juvenile hares trapped
was 31.5 with a median annual number of 18.5 (Table 1, Figure 1). There
is an overall decline in the annual counts of juvenile snowshoe hare for
the period 1999-2012. However, the number of days and traps in the study
were not standardized for each year, limiting the utility of this
methodology for accurately estimating the juvenile hare population.
B.
Juvenile snowshoe hare weights comparison by sex and site



Figure 2. Weight (g) for juvenile snowshoe hare by
sex and site (Bonanza Black Spruce, Bonanza Mature, and Bonanza
Riparian). Gold (female), teal (male) and coral (NA) points indicate
individual observations for weight (grams) of juvenile snowshoe hare.
Box endpoints indicate the 25th and 75th
percentile values. The black line and black point within the box
indicate the weights median and mean value respectively. Data: Kielland
et al. (2017).
C. Juvenile
hare mean weights comparison by sex
Distributions of weights (plots not included) for juvenile male and
female snowshoe hares were relatively normal and symmetric (bell-shaped
histogram and quantile-quantile plot with an almost linear
relationship).
Table 2. Descriptive statistics (mean, standard
deviation, and sample size) for weights (g) of juvenile snowshoe hare
trappings by sex. Data: Kielland et al. (2017).


Sex


Mean Weight (g)


Standard deviation (g)


Sample Size


f


855.4


292.3


197


m


945.9


333.2


163





On average, juvenile snowshoe hare males weight slightly more than
female juvenile snowshoe hares (945.86 \(\pm\) 333.22 and 855.39 \(\pm\) 292.25 g, respectively; mean \(\pm\) 1 standard deviation). The absolute
difference in means is 90.47 g (a 10.05% difference). The effect size is
small (Cohen’s d = 0.29) and the difference in means is
significant (Welch two-sample t-test: t(325.02) = 2.71, p <
0.001).
D.
Relationship between juvenile snowshoe hare weight & hind foot
length
The relationship between hind foot length (mm) and weight (g) was
explored for juvenile snowshoe hares by simple lineal regression.
Additional variables as sex or sites were not included in the
analysis.



Figure 3. Relationship between hind foot length (mm)
and weight (g) for juvenile snowshoe hares. Points indicate individual
juvenile snowshoe hare measurements. Linear model summary: \(\beta\)1 = 9.52 g
mm-1, p < 0.001, R2 = 0.3, Pearson’s r
= 0.55). An equation of this linear model is also displayed in the plot
panel. Data: Kielland et al. (2017).
The relationship between hind foot length (mm) and weight (g) for
juvenile snowshoe hares appears relatively linear (Figure 3). Simple
linear regression showed that hind foot length is not a strong predictor
of juvenile snowshoe hares weight (p < 0.001, R2 = 0.3);
i.e., only 29.88% of the variance in weight is predictable from the hind
foot length. The average slope is \(\beta\) = 9.52 g mm-1; meaning
that, on average, we expect weight to increase by 9.52grams for each one
millimeter increase in hind foot length. Hind foot length and weight are
moderately, and significantly, positively correlated (Pearson’s
r = 0.55, p < 0.001). Diagnostic plots (not included) reveal
normally distributed (with a slight skew to the right) residuals.The
heteroscedasticity of residuals shown in these plots is a major concern.
Linear regression assumes that all residuals are drawn from a population
that has a constant variance of the error (homoscedasticity);
heteroscedasticity can decrease the predictive capacity of the linear
model by underestimating or overestimating uncertainty.
Summary
Juvenile hares data exploration reveals the following findings:
There is a decrease in the observations of juvenile snowshoe
hares (observed via trap capture) from 1999 to 2012. However, as the
number of days and traps in each year of the study were not standardized
it is difficult to accurately estimate the real variation in the
juvenile hare population.
Juvenile snowshoe hare males weight, on average, slightly more
than female juvenile snowshoe hares. The difference in means is
significant but the effect size is small (Cohen’s d =
0.29).
The linear regression exploration of the relationship between
hind foot length and weight for juvenile snowshoe hares revealed that
hind foot length is not a strong predictor of weight (p < 0.001,
R2 = 0.3). At the same time, the observed heteroscedasticity
of residuals weakens the predictive capacity of this model.
Citations
Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and Bonanza Creek LTER.
2017.Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest:
1999-Present ver 22. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14

title: Macronutrients and Energy Content in Beef Products, Pork Products, and Poultry Products
description: In this analysis, I explored the relationship between protein, carbohydrate, fat, and energy content in three food groups (Beef Products, Pork Products, and Poultry Products) using Principal Components Analysis (PCA). PCA is a statistical technique used to reduce the dimensionality of multivariate data while retaining as much information as possible. This allows for easier visualization and identification of patterns, relationships, and outliers. The results were visualized using a biplot, where the first two principal components explained 80% of the variance in the data, revealing strong correlations between certain macronutrients and the distinct clustering of food groups.
contents:
Introduction
In this report, I explore the variables protein, carbohydrate, fat,
and energy content in three different food groups (Beef Products, Pork
Products, and Poultry Products) by performing a Principal Components
Analysis (PCA) and reflecting this information on a biplot. PCA is an
ordination method used to visualize patterns in multivariate data that
allows to reframe multivariate data in a simplified number of dimensions
while retaining as much information as possible. This way, PCA enables
us to easily explore the relationship between the variables and identify
multivariate patterns and outliers. Data for this report was taken from
the USDA National Nutrient Database (https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/).






Figure 1. Biplot of the PCA ordination performed for
the variables protein, carbohydrate, fat, and energy content in three
different food groups. Orange dots represent observations for Beef
Products, blue squares for Pork Products, and green triangles for
Poultry Products. Their position reflects the score of each observation
based on the principal components (PC1 and PC2). Distance between
observations approximate the Euclidean distance and allow assessing
similarity in multivariate space and identifying multivariate groups and
outliers. Arrows show the loading of variables for each principal
component (PC1 and PC2). Their length indicates variance in the
principal component direction (PC1 horizontal component and PC2 vertical
component); the angle between them shows the variables correlation. Data
USDA (2019).
Summary
Displayed PCA biplot describes 80% of variance in the analyzed data
(PC1 55% and PC2 25%). The arrows convey information about the examined
variables. The small angle separating the variables fat and energy
reveals a strong positive correlation between them. In turn, these
variables are negatively correlated with protein and not highly
correlated with carbohydrates (almost right angle). At the same time,
the distribution of observation in the biplot enables recognizing
multivariate groups and outliers. Here we can observe a big cluster of
multivariate similar observations in the center of the biplot and some
outlier observations extending vertically (poultry products) and
horizontally (mainly beef and pork products).
Citation:
U.S. Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service.
FoodData Central, 2019. https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/
